Just... just try to imagine the art on that card.

201097: Lu Meng, Wu General.author: DarthParallax
201097: Lu Meng, Wu General.text_parsed:
littlebeast- challenge accepted! for bonus points, I also actually found a Design that allowed me to beat yours, AND was flavorful to boot. Your clockwork pegasi thingies didn't really impress me enough on that mark.

5BBBWW

The God Damn Batman, Dark Knight Detective

Legendary Creature-- Human Horror Vigilante (vMv) *not Mythic Rare: Bat-Rare.

Horsemanship, Flying, Shadow, Intimidate, Vigilance
Batman may block creatures with Intimidate as though they didn't have Intimidate.

If you are being attacked at night, Batman gains flash until end of turn and you can play him without paying his mana cost. If you do, return Batman to your hand at the end of the combat step.
Whenever Batman deals combat damage to a player at night, that player discards two cards unless you draw two cards.

T: Double-Fight target creature (Batman deals damage equal to twice his power to target creature)
0: You may put an artifact card you own from outside of the game into your hand. Activate this ability only any time something happens, and only put cards that are exactly what you need into your hand this way. (Equipments named 'Sword of....' are artifact cards)

2/3

Let me clarify: I in no way meant for this to be a fair card. If it were, it wouldn't be the God Damn Batman, now, would it? =D

Here's the Oracle Text I made:
Creatures cannot block Batman.
Libraries cannot outsmart Batman.
Planeswalkers cannot have more gadgets than Batman.


Here's the Revised Oracle Text I made:
He's the God Damn Batman.
Update: Knight Exemplar does not actually make Batman Indestructible. I do have my limits.

=D

Also combos with Friday NIGHT Magic LoL

201117: Akron Legionnaire.author: Mode
201117: Akron Legionnaire.text_parsed:
Wizards was way too warry when designing this card back then.
Apparently afraid of creating a big white guy for the lategame, they designed this pitious card of chunk.
Requires double-white, yet has only half the cost's toughness?
Can with 8 mana only be cast in the lategame where such a creature isn't that intimidating anyways, yet has nothing but a huge drawback that prevents the majority of your creatures from attacking?
A creature with a cost that high should actually provide the opposite.

201124: Spiny Starfish.author: Mode
201124: Spiny Starfish.text_parsed:
Not that there are many of them in the first place,
but this is probably blue's most annoying chump blocker card. (The other one got printed in the next set as a rare.)

"Alright, i'll block your fattie and regenerate for . Oh yeah, and i also get another Starfish next turn - you know,
just in case you were thinking of attacking with that second fattie there you've just casted."

Well, that's of course assuming your opponent's fatties don't have evasion or trample.
And keep diving to the ground of the ocean when they attempt to attack you.

Still, this card would make an awesome reprint.
Or an almost-functional reprint, since the trigger is a bit quirky (in case they want to put it in a Core Set).

201124: Spiny Starfish.author: Aquillion
201124: Spiny Starfish.text_parsed:
@crackmore: Doesn't work, read the rulings.

"Spiny Starfish's first ability creates a regeneration shield for it. Spiny Starfish's second ability checks whether it _used_ any regeneration shields that turn, not whether any regeneration shields were created for it."

This card is amusing and fun, but not particularly powerful. Sure, you could find ways to use the tokens, but you also have to find a way to kill it repeatedly to create them, and at that point you'd be better off using some other source of tokens. And while blue has few options for token-generators, it also has fewer ways of using them than most colors...

201127: Cleanse.text_parsed:
It costs the same as Wrath, so many people would dismiss it as sub-par.... But it is actually really, really good sideboard material for any non-black deck with even a bit of white or, hell, even a deck with a bit of black!

Also keep in mind, however, that it is much more like Day of Judgment than Wrath, since the creatures can regenerate. In black, that could be a problem, where there are Drudge Skeletons running around.

201128: Jedit Ojanen.author: sir_dwar
201128: Jedit Ojanen.text_parsed:
It really says something about this card's badness when you see how much he changed for the planar chaos version compared to the others.

Crovax- Gets +1/+1 and a pay 2 life: bounce him ability, loses flying (since he isn't a vampire anymore)
Braids- Puts cards onto the battlefield instead of sacing them
Akroma- Colorshifted protections, Trades haste, first strike, and vigilance for uncounterable, morph and firebreathing
Mirri- P/T switched, Gains flying instead of forestwalk and haste instead of vigilance, and gets the traditional vampire feeding ability for +1 CMC
Jedit- Loses 1 cmc, gains forestwalk and the ability to make 2/2 forestwalking cat tokens whenever he attacks or blocks.

201128: Jedit Ojanen.author: Radagast
201128: Jedit Ojanen.text_parsed:
One of those Legends that so badly needs an ability to match the coolness of the flavor.

I sometimes wonder if they just ran out of time when making that set... Why make a set full of supposedly epic "Legends" that helped shape the game world, and then make so many of them boring, overcosted lumps that lack abilities. I can understand why they were overpriced - almost all creatures were back then - but how does "Amazing cat warrior" equal "blank text box 5/5 for 7 mana of two colors?!"

Heck, at least give him Plainswalk or something, as random as that would be.

201128: Jedit Ojanen.author: Authority
201128: Jedit Ojanen.text_parsed:
When I first got into this game, it was because of cards as insanely overpowered as this. With all of the tricks around in the game these days, it's possible to consistently play cards like this by turn 4 with the likes of quicksilver amulet.

This bad boy has a presence when it hits the field that not even Storm Crow or Chimney Imp can match. When this guy hits the field its impossible not to stare at his beautiful mane blowing in the wind. The prowess that is a 5/5 creature for 7 mana - and it only takes 2 colours to get him onto the field if you hardcast.

The best part is, if you have Liquimetal Coating you can't even kill him with Go for the Throat.

If you have 2 x Heartless Summoning out you can drop this badboy by turn 4 as a 3/3 - Ouch!

This guy puts your opponent on a 4 turn clock, by turn 7 - be careful!

201129: Cosmic Horror.author: Iasonas
201129: Cosmic Horror.text_parsed: To those who wonder why this card has such a bad drawback, remember the environment when the card was first made. Drawbacks were made on some cards to prevent opponents from taking full advantage of a card. Players with Animate Dead, Resurrection, and Control Magic would have a field day if cards such as Cosmic Horror , Mold Demon, and Force of Nature have no drawbacks. It takes a lot of resources for a mono-colored mage to cast his power card and we don't want them feeling cheated when someone just steals it away from them with nothing to lose. Most people in the earliest days of Magic run only a single color.
201129: Cosmic Horror.text_posted: To those who wonder why this card has such a bad drawback, remember the environment when the card was first made. Drawbacks were made on some cards to prevent opponents from taking full advantage of a card. Players with [autocard]Animate Dead[/autocard], [autocard]Resurrection[/autocard], and [autocard]Control Magic[/autocard] would have a field day if cards such as [autocard]Cosmic Horror [/autocard], [autocard]Mold Demon[/autocard], and [autocard]Force of Nature[/autocard] have no drawbacks. It takes a lot of resources for a mono-colored mage to cast his power card and we don't want them feeling cheated when someone just steals it away from them with nothing to lose. Most people in the earliest days of Magic run only a single color.

201129: Cosmic Horror.author: chicollicolli
201129: Cosmic Horror.text_parsed:
I'm surprised that no one here has picked up on, or has at least commented about, the obvious Lovecraft influence with regards to this card.

With the name cosmic horror and it's amorphous disposition this looks like a card depiction of Azathoth, the blind idiot god, or a shoggoth.
Probably the shoggoth, the blind idiot would surely have to be many times more powerful than a 7/7.

Here's a shoggoth quote, "a shapeless congeries of protoplasmic bubbles, faintly self-luminous, and with myriads of temporary eyes forming and un-forming." - H.P. Lovecraft, At the Mountains of Madness.

Doesn't Cosmic Horror fit that de***ion nicely? Why yes.

Doesn't Cosmic Horror fit that description nicely? Why yes.

201130: Crimson Kobolds.author: Ferlord
201130: Crimson Kobolds.text_parsed:
@ Arachnos

Then it's not strictly worse.

A card that is strictly worse is one that is identical to another card, but is worse by just 1 aspect. For example, Scathe Zombies is strictly worse than Walking Corpse, because although they're both 2/2 Black Zombies, Scathe Zombies costs while Walking Corpse costs .

A common example of a "strictly better" argument is Fugitive Wizard and Memnite. Sure, Fugitive Wizard costs while Memnite costs , but what if you had Azami, Lady of Scrolls on the field? You'd then have a 1-cost Archivist instead.
What if you played Mass Appeal? Memnite wouldn't draw you that extra card. What if you played Kessig Macontents? Memnite wouldn't add 1 more damage to the spell.

Not only that, but you JUST proved that it isn't strictly better! You said "Unless you consider being red or being a kobold as an advantage for some reason". What if you had a deck that benefited from being Red? Would Ornithopter be better? Most likely not.

People always say "Strictly better", but in all truth, there are very, VERY few examples of cards which as strictly better than others.

201139: Ghosts of the Damned.author: Radagast
201139: Ghosts of the Damned.text_parsed:
Proves that R&D was a very vague concept back in the day...

Designer 1: "You know, Scathe Zombies are kinda weak... maybe we should make a stronger version?"

Designer 2: "OKay, like a tap ability to make something weaker... oh, but we'll make it cost more to cast."

Designer 1: "Argh - no! A 2/2 for 1BB that taps to give a creature -1/-0 until end of turn! Way too broken! This will let you kill a Pearled Unicorn while your Scathe Zombie lives! We need to fix it!"

Designer 2: "Yeah, okay. Maybe we can make it an 0/2 - that way, nobody will use it."

Designer 1: "Excellent!

201144: Old Man of the Sea.author: ErikLauer
201144: Old Man of the Sea.text_parsed:
Erik's Random card 6/23/2011

I was playing when Arabian Nights was released. I liked Control Magic, but it was a bit too good (and annoying) so people complained, and I switched to Royal Assassin and Prodigal Sorcerer (Tim). I loved Old Man because it still took stuff, but wasn't quite as good at it, and was easier to deal with. People didn't complain :)

When I was designing Masters Edition III, initially I had In the Eye of Chaos instead of Old Man of the Sea. ME 3 is primarily composed of cards from Legends, The Dark, and Portal Three Kingdoms. In the Eye of Chaos is in Legends. Old Man is in Arabian Nights, so by set it would be in Master's Edition IV.

I decided to sketch out ME 4, and see what it looked like. I noticed both Control Magic and Old Man of the Sea were in that set. They are very powerful limited cards with very similar effects, and I thought it would be more fun to only have one in each set. I picked Old Man to go in ME 3; ME4 was going to have Beta, and thus look more like a loaded core set. Control Magic is the clean card I would expect in a core set.

I also wrote a note to remind Tom when development started about In the Eye of Chaos. I explained the situation to him. He could go with any of In the Eye of Chaos, Old Man of the Sea, and Control Magic. He said leaving both for ME 4 was just wrong, and that Control Magic belongs in ME 4. So Old Man stayed in this set.

Sometimes we spend a lot of time trying to iron out little details that no one notices. Often that is all we are hoping for!

201150: Kobold Taskmaster.author: achilleselbow
201150: Kobold Taskmaster.text_parsed: It doesn't boost itself. Look at the card. Before they changed the way creature types were printed, the creature type was whatever appeared after "summon". Pretty much all the "overlord" creatures that were printed then have a different type than the tribe they are giving a bonus to (see Lord of Atlantis, for example). Now they count as those types, but to keep the card functioning the same way, they've added errata that say "other ____ creatures". This does make a minor difference, however, in that if you have two of them out they will now give each other the bonus, whereas before they would not have.
201150: Kobold Taskmaster.text_posted: It doesn't boost itself. Look at the card. Before they changed the way creature types were printed, the creature type was whatever appeared after "summon". Pretty much all the "overlord" creatures that were printed then have a different type than the tribe they are giving a bonus to (see [autocard]Lord of Atlantis[/autocard], for example). Now they count as those types, but to keep the card functioning the same way, they've added errata that say "other ____ creatures". This does make a minor difference, however, in that if you have two of them out they will now give each other the bonus, whereas before they would not have.

201153: Land Tax.author: Akromar
201153: Land Tax.text_parsed:
A very awesome card in decks that utilize things like Wild Mongrel and similar cards, because it can give you a ton of fodder to drop from your hand. Also is really great for thinning out your deck. Even if you only get 3 lands out of it over the course of the game that's half the cost of a rampant growth you paid for those 3 lands.

Also, if you go second in a 1v1, here's how you do it.

Turn 1: Opponent drops a land, does whatever. On your first turn, drop a land and play something (this is important!)
Turn 2: Your opponent drops a land, and does whatever. On your second turn you play this,but don't play a land.
Turn 3: Your opponent touches face to palm when they realize you're getting 3 lands next turn.

It's an early play that may lose you tempo early on, but hopefully your land advantage later on will help you in the midgame.

It's an early play that may lose you tempo early on, but hopefully your land advantage later on will help you in the midgame.

201156: Mana Drain.author: Olliemancer
201156: Mana Drain.text_parsed:
Even though it doesn't go in every deck, I can say having played with 4 of those babies in my deck from may until now that it really is amazing what those can do. It's really fun to see your combo get out two or three turns earlier or cast a Wheel of Fortune or a Timetwister for 1 mana and then have the rest of your mana free for your new hand... or even worse, still having mana left from your mana drain after having drawn your new hand of seven cards. This really puts you on another power level. :)

As Death said to Hector in Curse of Darkness: "Your efforts have been a great boon to me."

201156: Mana Drain.author: quadibloc
201156: Mana Drain.text_parsed: When this card was originally designed, there was only one main phase, and the combat step took place during the main phase. So the ruling that using it during the precombat main phase or combat causes the mana to arrive during the postcombat main phase of the same turn is a substantive change to what the card does. Instead, it should have received an erratum so that the Sixth Edition rules change would not have altered its behavior.
201156: Mana Drain.text_posted: When this card was originally designed, there was only one main phase, and the combat step took place during the main phase. So the ruling that using it during the precombat main phase or combat causes the mana to arrive during the postcombat main phase of the same turn is a substantive change to what the card does. Instead, it should have received an erratum so that the Sixth Edition rules change would not have altered its behavior.

201156: Mana Drain.author: Pontiac
201156: Mana Drain.text_parsed:
I remember playing a partners tourny and my partner used the high tide combo to cast a million point fireball, one guy Drained it, I couldn't do anything I was out of counterspells. My partner Wheel of Fortuned. I pulled a drain, 2 force of wills and a counterspell plus Time Walk, Twister and a land. The guy casts his own million point fireball with the drain mana, I drain it, he counters it, I counterspell back, He force of wills (the hard way) I force ditching the Walk, his partner counters I Force again tossing Twister. it happens, my turn I draw a card it was a pearl, I was about to dump the mana into a mishras factory when my partner ancestrals me, I draw Braingesyer, land and Fork, Best tourny win ever, Million point Braingesyer forked to both of them.

My friend and I laughed about that one for ever, every time we'd play a drain, fork or geyser we'd start chuckling.

201156: Mana Drain.author: TyrroxZym
201156: Mana Drain.text_parsed:
For those wondering how they could have made a card that was so powerful I figured I would share with you the following:
Back when Legends was released Wizards was a VERY different company, and Richard Garfield's team did not actually design the Legend's set, a Canadian Graduate school did, and because of the distance and communication issues (Internet wasn't what it is today back then) there were a lot of issues with deciding the casting costs of cards. That is why you will notice the casting costs of cards all over the place, and why many cards are over-costed for what they do, even back then. Mana Drain is one of the few cards from the set that ended up being broken by most people's standards.

Read this article by Steve Menendian to learn more about the beginnings of Magic; its a great read all Magic players should read!
http://www.eternalcentral.com/?p=3289

201156: Mana Drain.author: Aquillion
201156: Mana Drain.text_parsed:
If you cast it on a spell that uses up all your opponent's mana (which is what generally happens in the early game against competent opponents), you're basically denying them a card and all of that turn's mana, and getting an extra turn's mana for yourself.

In other words, it's basically Time Walk, but it costs your opponent a card instead of giving one to you (and you get to choose what card, which is generally more powerful than a draw!) Yes, that's right, in the right situation this card is more powerful than Time Walk.

The only reason it's (marginally) less powerful than Time Walk overall is because it's slightly situational, while Time Walk works at absolutely any time; but given that the 'situation' is essentially "the enemy casts a big spell and you have a big spell you want to cast", that's not exactly much of a drawback.

(Alright, and Time Walk also gives you an extra attack and land drop. But still.)

201156: Mana Drain.author: ox411
201156: Mana Drain.text_parsed:
It's hard to say if this is the best counter spell ever printed or the second best. Sometimes you need a Mana Drain and sometimes you need a Force of Will. Either way this card is so powerful it seems like it shouldnt have ever been printed. Depending on the hand I draw, I like to use it as an offensive weapon as well as a counterspell. Counter some little spell my opponent plays on the first or second turn, and on my next turn my mind twist is even better. If Ive got a dark ritual or some power 9 artifacts I can empty your hand on the second or third turn. The fact that it also counters a spell you just cast is kind of a bonus at that point.
There used to be an occasional 'downside' to playing it, in that you would sometimes wind up with more mana then you could spend on your next turn, but since they changed the mana burn rule, Mana Drain has gotten even better.
Its not on the 'reserved list' and it doesnt need to be. Theyll never print this card again, its just too good
Every blue deck Ive ever made has 4 of these in it.

201158: Nether Void.author: Ragamander
201158: Nether Void.text_parsed:
@Yozuk and drpvfx:

Okay guys, according to Rule 614.6, Guile's ability causes a modified event (exiling the spell and playing/casting it) to occur instead of the original countering of the spell by Nether Void, and this event may in turn trigger abilities. So, if Guile's ability allows you to "cast" the card, then this can cause an infinite casting loop (which could be used to build up an arbitrarily large storm count).

However, according to Rule 701.10d, cards that refer to casting cards as "playing" them have all been updated in Oracle to refer to "casting" that card. If this is true, and since Guile's ability apparently still reads "you may play that card," then I'd doubt that the card is actually being cast; rather, it seems like it is being put directly onto the stack, as a copy of a spell with Replicate or Storm might be, I suppose. Except, according to Rule 701.10b, "to play a card means to play that card as a land or to cast that card as a spell, whichever is appropriate." So it must mean "you may cast that card," right? The Oracle rulings all use the "cast" terminology, so maybe the Oracle text for the actual card just somehow escaped being updated.

My guess is that the word "play" was just overlooked, and it really should read "cast" like Isochron Scepter. But, in the end, it's a totally valid question that probably needs answering by somebody more well-qualified than I am.

So, if [autocard]Guile[/autocard]'s ability allows you to "cast" the card, then this can cause an infinite casting loop (which could be used to build up an arbitrarily large storm count).

[i]However[/i], according to Rule 701.10d, cards that refer to casting cards as "playing" them have all been updated in Oracle to refer to "casting" that card. [i]Except[/i], according to Rule 701.10b, "to play a card means to play that card as a land or to cast that card as a spell, whichever is appropriate." So it must mean "you may [i]cast[/i] that card," right? The Oracle rulings all use the "cast" terminology, so maybe the Oracle text for the actual card just somehow escaped being updated.

My guess is that the word "play" was just overlooked, and it really should read "cast" like [autocard]Isochron Scepter[/autocard]. But, in the end, it's a totally valid question that probably needs answering by somebody more well-qualified than I am.

201158: Nether Void.author: drpvfx
201158: Nether Void.text_parsed:
Okay, everyone- I got a ruling from three different judges, and they all said the same thing:
If I have Guile and Nether Void in play, then I cast a spell and let Nether Void counter it,
it will still require 3 to resolve when it comes out of Guile.
Not paying that 3 will cause the spell to fail again, and Guile can cast it again.
This can be repeated to build up a Storm count as high as you wish,
and then you can kill an entire table of creatures and players with a single Grapeshot.

Not quite as fun as what I had in mind,
but I still think I'm going to be using this combo... I just need to add some Storm cards to the deck.

201160: Force Spike.author: Hermeezey
201160: Force Spike.text_parsed:
IMO: Force Spike > Mental Misstep.

Most decks only run one-drops for aggro and curve considerations. Force Spike either forces your opponent to leave one extra mana open or get hard-countered, which means their tempo and curve is basically one whole land-drop behind. Mental Misstep might hard counter the first 1-mana drop, but after saving you that 2 or 3 extra damage, you'll still have to face down this 2,3, and 4 drop. Mid-game when is when mana becomes tight for stompy aggro decks, and Force Spike pretty much acts as a hard counter if your opponents ramp is fine-tuned to be as efficient as possible. I guess what I'm trying to say is that Force Spike still has a bit of value later in the game because it makes your opponent play with one-mana open and keeps them from tapping out for their finishers. And all of this is assuming your opponent knows you have a force spike in hand. If they don't and try to tap out, well then you just gained CA by hard countering for one blue mana.

Mental Misstep is a freebie cast if you don't go first and only hard-counters a 1 CMC card. Which means if you are going first or if they don't open with 1-drops or if you don't have Mental Misstep in your opening hand, Mental Misstep loses a lot of its power and takes up a card space of another more useful counter. Now when you are drifting into turns 3,4, and 5 where mana is still tight for the big stompies, all the stuff you could counter with Mental Misstep wouldn't be worth countering anyways. (I mean, at best you would be looking at countering a lightning bolt but you would usually pay 2 life for Misstep anyways, so whats the point?)

However, Mental Misstep essentially costs 0 mana, which makes it a bane to all combo decks. But if you are playing in a competitive environment where everyone is running crazy combo-decks in the meta-game, you would be much better off with Force of Will anyways.

201161: Recall.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
201161: Recall.text_parsed:
@Darkcider: *ba-dum-dum, ts!* =)

I opened one of these from a pack of Chronicles a long time ago and I wasn't impressed. Reflecting on it now, though, I'm sure that I misjudged the card. I tried pulling up a list of cards that allow you to recur *any* card type from your graveyard to your hand, and the list isn't very long:

Elven Cache
Eternal Witness
Nostalgic Dreams
Recollect
Regrowth
Restock
Woodland Guidance

Of these, only two let you target multiple cards, and only one lets you target more than two... more importantly, though, these cards are all green. Recall gives general recursion to a colour that really doesn't have it, and even at such high cost, it seems like a pretty decent effect.

On a different note: the 5th edition version has new art, which is cool... but then they went back to the original art for 6th edition. Wierd. Not sure what's happening in either art, specifically, though I can at least tell that this mage must be recalling in a graveyard while wearing a bird on her head.

On a different note: the [autocard multiverseid="3936"]5th edition version[/autocard] has new art, which is cool... but then they went back to the original art for [autocard multiverseid="11467"]6th edition[/autocard].  Wierd.  Not sure what's happening in either art, specifically, though I can at least tell that this mage must be recalling in a graveyard while wearing a bird on her head.

Amazing EDH general in 1-on-1 mono-black control. Lets you recur Tutors with Corpse Dance. Then its just a matter of getting the right cards at the right time. 201164: Xiahou Dun, the One-Eyed.author: cgermain
201164: Xiahou Dun, the One-Eyed.text_parsed: I run this guy in a Chainer, Dementia Master EDH deck. Just got to really play him for the first time and I have to say, probably one of the most exciting cards to draw in the deck. Four mana and I get to recur any spell in my 'yard? Sign me up. Card that synergizes with death triggers and can be targeted by reanimation spells, and is nigh-unblockable? Icing on the cake. In a recent game that I played, I played a Temporal Extrortion on turn 4, dropped this guy the next turn an sac'd him, nabbed the Extortion from my yard, and played it again using Lake of the Dead. After I got Chainer out in a couple of turns, I proceeded to recur the extortion multiple time using mana from Black Market and the Lake. One of my opponents even offered up half their life to counter an extortion, and I had enough mana to cast it a second time. All in all it was a series of interactions that was a blast to play and made the game we were playing interesting for me and for my opponents. I think it's always really fun to find interactions between cards that you wouldn't usually see, and I think that this card in particular is an excellent enabler

201166: Demonic Torment.author: Aquillion
201166: Demonic Torment.text_parsed:
Legends was an odd set -- its cards were all over the place in terms of balance, it was way before we had a proper color pie, and it had a few ideas that just didn't work.

But at the same time, it had a lot of good ideas (legends and multicolored cards, of course, but also the origins of shroud and the like.)

This is one of those oddball cards that still the seed of a good idea in it -- even if the effect eventually became white and got improved a bit.

Anyway, this really doesn't fit black at all -- it's almost entirely defensive, since it still lets the creature block. In fact, it's even more defensive than the actual pacifism-style effects white eventually got.
201166: Demonic Torment.text_posted:

201167: The Abyss.author: achilleselbow
201167: The Abyss.text_parsed: Interesting sidenote: it looks like the Oracle text went out of its way to specifically NOT call it sacrifice. 201167: The Abyss.author: Kragash
201167: The Abyss.text_parsed:
"This is an EXTREMELY powerful card. It can crush creature decks. Newer cards with similar abilities either destroy themselves or allow opponents to counter their ability. Cards like this make me always have enchantment destruction in my decks."

But newer cards with similar abilities (Porphyry Nodes for example) also:
- don't target creatures (and thus can hit shroud and hexproof creatures),
- hit creatures that have most likely just come out of summoning sickness (lower casting cost creatures),
- you get to choose the creature when there's a tie,
- and, above all, cost 4 times less (and thus creates the eternal debate for the opponent of "should I use this 2cmc enchantment removal on this self-destructing 1cmc enchantment")

Sure, the the newer cards leave play when there are no more targets, but this means it's either going to act like The Abyss if your opponent is aggressive... or it's going to clear whatever is already on the Battlefield and give you three full turns (unless you're being attacked by manlands or creatures with haste). The opponent needs to stop casting creatures for at least one turn in the case of Drop of Honey and Porphyry Nodes for those enchantments to be sacrificed. Then they can cast creatures on the next turn. Then they can attack subsequent turns. You effectively (and in most cases) get 3 turns of peace and quiet for a or a ... or you get a The Abyss-like effect (where the enchantment is always in effect because your opponent is trying to outrace the creature loss) that hits shroud and hexproof creatures for a or a .

Drop of Honey and Porphyry Nodes outclasses The Abyss in almost every situation except when you believe that you need more than 3-4 turns to pull off your game winning combo. Pro tip: if it takes more than 3-4 turns to pull off your combo after Drop of Honey or Porphyry hits the table, the issue is probably not that you should have been using The Abyss instead.

201175: Angus Mackenzie.author: Salient
201175: Angus Mackenzie.text_parsed:
If you equip this guy with a Loxodon Warhammer, you get a powerful beater that puts your opponent on a four-turn clock. To make sure you're knocking out one-fourth of your opponent's life with each swing, and keep him protected, you can equip him with Whispersilk Cloak. Yeah, that's kinda corny, but...

...there are two kinds of people in the world, those who are currently wondering who the heck would write such an idiotic comment encouraging the use of a fine-tuned turbo-fog control-deck icon as a badly-costed generic 2/2... and those who realized I was building an Angus Quarter Pounder with Cheese.

201176: Arboria.author: Psychrates
201176: Arboria.text_parsed:
One of the best cards from the best set post-Beta, not to see another rival in strength and scope until the Urza Block.

Far from being over-costed in it's time, most cards of The Legends set were made with unwieldy and high CMC by today's standards because of their unique win condition ability. Let's take a few for instance:

Johan: Ugly CMC, huh?

Not at all.

This was the Era of Personal Incarnation, Force of Nature, Mahamoti Djinn, Island Fish Jasconius, Lord Of The Pit

The next most powerful creature in this set is a Craw Wurm. Take a look.


Something like a 5/4 for 6 in ANY form that gave ALL creatures vigilance without further penalty was almost insurmountable. In this era, combat was actually a war of attrition(and not parlor tricks), attacking left you open with few options if any.

Let's do one more: Vaevictis Asmadi Ridiculously expensive and hopelessly out of date, eh?

In his era, the only 7/7 flyer is Lord Of The Pit.

He is a minimum of 10/7.

The benefit of saving card slots by removing a Howl from Beyond, a Firebreathing, furthermore doing so in green to boot. Plus he's a Dragon. Plus he's a Legend.

Legends were meant to be unique, that is, that their abilites would not be seen on other cards.

201178: Axelrod Gunnarson.author: scumbling1
201178: Axelrod Gunnarson.text_parsed: @ Dr.Pingas: That system of evaluating a card's mana cost didn't work fifteen years ago, and it doesn't now. Expensive creatures can afford to have more abilities and power for their mana cost, as they tend to be much less efficient then the removal your opponents have. Furthermore, they're coming into play against a battlefield that has had time to be populated; most fatties need to address concerns like being chump-blocked and making an immediate impact on the board, lest they simply don't have any impact depsite their size and expense.
201178: Axelrod Gunnarson.text_posted: @ Dr.Pingas: That system of evaluating a card's mana cost didn't work fifteen years ago, and it doesn't now. 201184: Chromium.author: achilleselbow
201184: Chromium.text_parsed:
This is also terrible from a flavor perspective. Each of the Elder Dragons is a main color with two allied colors, and an ability that's supposed to reflect that color. So Nicol Bolas = Black = hand destruction. Vaevictis = Red = pumpable power. Palladia Mors = Green = trample. Arcades Sabboth = White = defense. Chromium = Blue = ...Rampage? Rampage is probably the most un-blue ability I can think of besides Haste.

Oh well, blue was ridiculously overpowered back then anyway.

201184: Chromium.author: axiobeta
201184: Chromium.text_parsed:
LAWL I was only 2 years old when rampage was a thing.
This card, at least for me, represents Wizards not yet aware of how to make their own game. Chromium could have been the damn poster boy for shroud, which was actually around in 1994. It could have made him a force to be reckoned with like some of his bros.
But no.
Our chum chromium gets an ability which is absolutely useless 99.99% of the time unless he has trample. Which is in precisely none of his colors.
This coupled with the fact that Wizards wasted the BLUE Elder Dragon is just sad.
No wonder Bolas killed this poor guy.

201190: Barl's Cage.author: jfre81
201190: Barl's Cage.text_parsed:
I used this a lot when I was a newb. It's still not bad. I don't even have one of these anymore, but if I did I might use it in artifact EDH. Got a creature that's going to die anyway? Sack it to Ashnod's Altar, get one more and you can lock something down for a turn. Note that it can target untapped creatures too, making them choose between using it and losing it for next turn, or not tapping it. Of course, maybe you could hit it with an Icy Manipulator too for more. And then you can hit it every turn to keep it locked down, and you can change around what gets locked down rather than using an aura to keep it tapped.

The Braid of Fire idea is a good one too, along with anything else that could produce surplus mana.

201191: Gwendlyn Di Corci.author: N03y3D33R
201191: Gwendlyn Di Corci.text_parsed:
The image quality here is horrendous, but if you can get a look at the art in better quality it's pretty cool!

We can all see the discarded blade on the pillow, owned by the "knight" of course, because who would keep a blade in the presence of an unarmed lady when you have been summoned to her bedchambers? A barely clothed woman can't possibly hide a blade, and she has no armor. She's defenseless, right?
Well this supposed knight certainly thought so, much to his immediate dismay.
The knight in the image is, in fact, holding a rather intimidating knife in his right hand, it's the same color as his shirt so it's a bit hard to spot at first glance. He is likely a hired assassin who played the role of a noble man with an innocent mind. However, Gwendlyn has beaten him at his own game and if you look carefully, she is holding a small blade to his throat, which is why he looks so surprised. Both of them had intentions to kill one another from the beginning, but Gwendlyn's wit outmatched the hired killers, an ability represented in her considerable P/T and random discard ability.

201193: Hazezon Tamar.author: ereidivh
201193: Hazezon Tamar.text_parsed:
I've been using this guy as my commander for a few months now - I traded out Rith, the Awakener for him. He works differently than Rith. The old deck would generate tokens through some means, use Rith to make more, and eventually overwhelm, with a 6/6 flying commander as a backup. It was always just a better idea to go for the commander damage, though, since Rith has to get through to make more tokens anyway. I mostly use Hazezon as a repeatable, increasing-cost sorcery to make a crapload of tokens, which lets me reliably have a presence.

I run a motherload of ramp effects, my favorites being Perilous Forays and Boundless Realms. I previously had more means of sacrificing him, but now I use High Market and Miren, the Moaning Well along with a few Tutors (Expedition Map, Sylvan Scrying and Reap and Sow, specifically).

Ramp is so important in this deck, because of the prevalence of board-wipe effects, so you can still cast Hazezon over and over. I run only 12 nonbasic lands in the deck, in case I run into an Armageddon, since I have a backup plan as Planar Birth.

I highly recommend him as a commander. Tokens are awesome.

201194: Hunding Gjornersen.author: oraymw
201194: Hunding Gjornersen.text_parsed:
This is such a strange card. It is a UW 5/4 with Rampage. How does that make any sense? In any case, I like the Legends Legends, simply because they are decent budget ways to make EDH decks. If I am playing on Magic Online, at least I can find a UW legend for cheap and put a deck together.

As for Rampage, it is a fascinating ability, but it is really depressing how easily it is for yoru opponent to avoid. For that reason, I have tried to avoid designing abilities that rely entirely on what your opponent does. It really leads to non-interactive games, and it is just frustrating with a card like this.

201194: Hunding Gjornersen.author: sonorhC
201194: Hunding Gjornersen.text_parsed: The "color pie" has always existed in some form; it's just that, in the early game, it tended to focus more on feel and flavor than on mechanics.  Thus, for instance, direct damage done by fire was red, but direct damage done by psychic power, or by a wizard on the battlefield, was blue.  But of course, Rampage doesn't really fit U/W that way, either, since they're supposed to be calm, methodical colors.

201197: Kjeldoran Frostbeast.author: EvilCowKing
201197: Kjeldoran Frostbeast.text_parsed:
Pardon the pun, but this thing is an absolute beast!

Want to wipe your opponents side of the board? Enchant with it Lure. Want to be a real @$$ about it? Play Nature's Revolt before giving it Lure.

Want to be sly? Swing with it, keep it alive with Giant Growth if you need to. When your opponent sees that you can no longer block with it and counter attacks with their best creatures, use Gerrard's Command, untap it, then Valor Made Real (all for 3 CMC no less) and destroy them all.

Want to just irritate your opponents? Run with U, cast Siren's Call during their pre-combat main phase, Valor Made Real this thing.

Seems to me like a real good card to enchant with Shield of the Oversoul.

201197: Kjeldoran Frostbeast.author: The_Jabberwocky
201197: Kjeldoran Frostbeast.text_parsed:
@EvilCowKing - you are wrong, sadly, none of your combos work as the Frostbeast will likely be dead before his effect can take place. See my comments below:

Hide Rulings
10/1/2009 Kjeldoran Frostbeast's ability triggers only if it's still on the battlefield when the end of combat step begins (after the combat damage step). For example, if it blocks a 7/7 creature and is destroyed, its ability won't trigger at all. The 7/7 will remain on the battlefield.
10/1/2009 Its ability will destroy all creatures it's currently blocking or blocked by, not necessarily the creatures it had blocked or become blocked by during that combat phase. For example, if Kjeldoran Frostbeast is dealt lethal combat damage and regenerates, it's removed from combat. Its ability will trigger at end of combat, but since it's no longer blocking or blocked by any creatures, the ability won't do anything.

These rulings are depressing and ruin this card. It was clearly meant to function the same as Thicket Basilisk when Ice Age went to print. It requires 2 different colored mana rather than only 1 so its perk was to not have the wall restriction. As mentioned by others, the identical wording on the 4th edition Thicket Basilisk proves this point. WotC gets 0/5 stars for this lame decision.
201197: Kjeldoran Frostbeast.text_posted:
[b]@EvilCowKing - you are wrong, sadly, none of your combos work as the Frostbeast will likely be dead before his effect can take place. See my comments below:[/b]

Hide Rulings
10/1/2009	Kjeldoran Frostbeast's ability triggers only if it's still on the battlefield when the end of combat step begins (after the combat damage step). For example, if it blocks a 7/7 creature and is destroyed, its ability won't trigger at all. The 7/7 will remain on the battlefield.
10/1/2009	Its ability will destroy all creatures it's currently blocking or blocked by, not necessarily the creatures it had blocked or become blocked by during that combat phase. For example, if Kjeldoran Frostbeast is dealt lethal combat damage and regenerates, it's removed from combat. Its ability will trigger at end of combat, but since it's no longer blocking or blocked by any creatures, the ability won't do anything.

[b]These rulings are depressing and ruin this card. It was clearly meant to function the same as Thicket Basilisk when Ice Age went to print. It requires 2 different colored mana rather than only 1 so its perk was to not have the wall restriction. As mentioned by others, the identical wording on the 4th edition Thicket Basilisk proves this point. WotC gets 0/5 stars for this lame decision.[/b]

201199: Illusionary Mask.author: Mode
201199: Illusionary Mask.text_parsed:
I agree that this is possibly the card with the weirdest (Oracle) wording in Magic.

To anyone who doesn't understand this card, it works something like this:
You pay a certain cost X equal (or higher) to the cmc of the creature card you want to put face down.
Now you basically have a common 2/2 Morph.
However, unlike regular Morphs, this one will turn face up far more easily - once it deals or is dealt damage, or if it becomes tapped.

I think the basic idea of this card was similar to the concept of regular Morphs from Onslaught that's more familiar to most players - this card should allow to trick your opponent by anonymizing your creature (therefore you can pay more than it would actually cost).
I can't think of any amazing surprise with the assert of creatures back then, though.

Well, the special and broken part about this card is the fact that it easily allows you to circumvent huge creature drawbacks, most notable triggered abilities that would normally resolve when the accordant fattie enters the battlefield - the aforementioned Phyrexian Dreadnought most notably for example.
If anyone now wonders why Stifle isn't banned then as well in Legacy should keep in mind that you don't have to sacrifice the Illusionary Mask once the creature gets turned up - you don't even have to tap it!
One Mask is enough to get multiple undercosted creatures out in one turn, and therefore it's only allowed in Vintage.

201199: Illusionary Mask.author: GainsBanding
201199: Illusionary Mask.text_parsed:
It's not that confusing. You use it to cast a creature (paying full normal casting cost) face down. Because Morph exists now, they've updated it so that face down creature is 2/2 like a morph creature (oracle had it as a 0/1 for a while). Then it turns face up whenever anything happens to it. But it's just not that good. You still cast the creature, so you can only do it on your turn at sorcery speed and it can still be countered. It does negate ETB effects, but since you still have to pay the actual casting cost, Phyrexian Dreadnought is the only stand-out creature to use with this.

However, weird interactions can happen and they obviously had to do a lot of rules wrangling to get this to work. It was like that from day 1. In Alpha, there was no answer for what happens if you cast a black creature face down with this and then it's targeted with terror. I guess that would be one of those "flip a coin if you can't figure out the rules" moments the original rule book mentioned.

In Alpha, there was no answer for what happens if you cast a black creature face down with this and then it's targeted with [autocard]terror[/autocard].  I guess that would be one of those "flip a coin if you can't figure out the rules" moments the original rule book mentioned.

Better yet, a facedown Platinum Angel meant you could simply tell your opponent you didn't lose after he flattened you with a herd of creatures and he simply had to take your word for it. This was the only card where you could technically lie to your opponent about the state of the game and he had no way to check against it.

201199: Illusionary Mask.author: GrimjawxRULES
201199: Illusionary Mask.text_parsed:
Confusing? Well yes, that's the point! :P

I know it's been done before, but here is what the card does:
You pay X where X is the exact casting cost (including colored mana) or more of a creature card in your hand (you can't pay less than that creature's casting cost, but you can pay more), then you cast that card face-down as a 2/2 creature. Then, as long as that creature is face down, if that creature would be tapped, dealt damage or if it would deal damage, the creature is turned face up.

The purpose of this card is solely to confuse the snot out of your opponents: you can pay overprice for your creatures and bluff that you're playing some kind of bomb, and since your opponent can't tell your creatures apart from one another, they might end up casting a Doom Blade targeting a face-down Llanowar Elves thinking that they're hitting one of your fatties.
Also, as far as I know, there isn't a rule that prevents you from moving your cards around on the table (or even shuffling them and laying them out on the table again). As such, you could shuffle your face-down cards and then lay them down on the table again. If your opponent figured out that you just cast a really good creature, he/she is going to have a hard time finding the right target for his/her removal spells until you've turned that creature face up (they certainly wouldn't want to risk hitting the wrong target). Even better is when that creature has shroud or hexproof to protect it from removal once it's actually turned face up.

Do remember that you (and only you) are allowed to look at face-down cards that you control that are on the battlefield, so you'll always be able to know which creature you're attacking or blocking with when that time comes.
Mind you, this usually doesn't apply to cards that remove cards from the game face-down, or cards that put cards face-down underneath them, unless those cards state that you're allowed to look at them.

This card is a blast to play in casual, but I recommend reading the rulings on the details-page if you're interested in trying it out before you do - it can answer a lot of your questions before you need to ask them.

My only complaint is that this card is so expensive to get a hold of, but other than that, this is a straight 5/5, just for the amount of fun it can generate, especially in multiplayer or perhaps even EDH if that's your thing.

EDIT: @Moleland: You would be correct in that assumption. As with morph, Illusionary Mask allows creatures that otherwise wouldn't be able to legally attack (defenders and creatures with other abilities that would render them unable to attack) to attack, meaning that you could technically have a Sunweb attack your opponent on your 5th turn without ramping.
Mind you, your face-down creature would still be unable to attack if it is affected by some external effect that renders it unable to attack (Pacifism, Blazing Archon or Moat (unless you have somehow given your face-down creature flying) etc.).

201199: Illusionary Mask.author: Megadog
201199: Illusionary Mask.text_parsed:
"X Mana: You may put a creature card with converted mana cost X or less from your hand onto the battlefield face down as a 0/1 creature. Put X mask counters on that creature. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery. The creature's controller may turn the creature face up any time he or she could cast an instant by removing all mask counters from it. This effect ends if the creature is turned face up."

That is such a functional change. While the power and toughness were never defined on the original card, and are still up for debate due to global -x/-x effects and stuff like fling, the card clearly requires you to pay it's casting cost, not it's mana cost. Furthermore, the mask counters are pointless and the face down creature can perform ulterior operations while 'morphed'. It can attack and block and deal damage, which further deviates from how this card operates. This summation is a way the card could have been done, but by no means does it do the cards ability justice.

201199: Illusionary Mask.author: JarieSuicune
201199: Illusionary Mask.text_parsed:
I love how it's this, when simplified:

Choose a Creature card in your hand.
Pay the creature's Casting Cost, and cast it face down as a 2/2 colorless creature.
--IGNORE ALL ENTERS THE BATTLEFIELD EFFECTS ON THAT CREATURE-- (or any others it has; it doesn't have them... yet)
If it would tap, take damage, assign damage, or deal damage, flip it face-up then have it tap, take damage, assign damage, or deal damage as normal (flipping does not go on the chain nor does it start one, it merely happens).

Your opponent doesn't know that you just played Phage the Untouchable.
Your opponent doesn't know that you just played Phyrexian Dreadnought.
Your opponent doesn't know that you just played (name an awesome but mid-cost card).
They don't know anything about what you played, and it cost you NO EXTRA MANA (beyond playing this card) to do so.

Sob... now if I could just GET me one of them...

201199: Illusionary Mask.author: CogMonocle

@GrimjawxRULES
Correct, except for the bit about shuffling around. You can't shuffle around creatures to confuse your opponents, as opponents are always aware of what objects are what, the battlefield being a public zone. If you cast a morph creature face down on turns 3 through 5, your oppponent knows which creature was played on what turn, no matter what. So you can't shuffle them to mess with your opponents.

201204: The Lady of the Mountain.author: DarthParallax
201204: The Lady of the Mountain.text_parsed:
She is supposed to look more like this: :P

25th-Level Epic Fighter, 26th-Level Sorcerer, 20th-Level Epic Spellsword


STR 22(+6) (+4 Belt of the Worldly)
DEX 28(+9) (+6 boots of swiftness)
CON 27(+8) (+4 Belt of the Worldly)
INT 19(+4)
WIS 21(+5)
CHA 20(+5)

Basically, in MTG terms, if a 1/1 is an average human creature and 10 is average DnD STR, but a 10/10 is impressive for a Magic creature and 20 is powerful for DnD, then we should subtract 10 from STR and from CON, leaving us with a 12/17 creature.

A 12/17 that also has basically "Protection from Everything, Flash, Flying, First Strike, Trample, Haste, Flying, Reach, Deathtouch, Lifelink, Vigilance, Shroud, Shadow, is Indestructible, can't be countered, and 'when you cast Lady of the Mountain, counter target spell' and 'when Lady of the Mountain enters the battlefield, put an X/X Pseudodragon Familiar token into play, where X is Lady of the Mountain's toughness', and 'when Lady of the Mountain dies, destroy all permanents' and {T}: Target player discards their hand and ' {0}: Target player draws a card.'


At least, that is how I would interpret this:
http://wizards.com/magic/magazine/article.aspx?x=mtgcom/arcana/47

201205: Life Chisel.author: yyukichigai
201205: Life Chisel.text_parsed:
There used to be an infinite life combo between this card and Nether Shadow, before the Shadow was errata'd to only trigger once during your upkeep. I used it quite a few times myself.

Great card for just about any creature-heavy deck. The upkeep restriction keeps it from being abused too much, and the casting cost is dead on for what it can potentially net you. I would welcome a reprint of this.

201206: Coal Golem.author: Nickajack
201206: Coal Golem.text_parsed:
So given the flavor text, the fireball either did:
8 damage to one target (x=8, no extra targets), or
3 damage to two targets (x=7, 1 extra target), or
2 damage to three targets (x=6, 2 extra targets), or
1 damage to four targets (x=5, 3 extra targets).

That's if the fellow using the golems decided to use their activated abilities, that is. But, we could also take this to mean that the planeswalker cast three of these guys before fireballing (it doesn't actually add any mana to activate their abilities after all). So that would be 15 mana available, and the ability to turn three of it into red (thus satisfying the red mana needed to cast fireball). So this puzzling mage instead cast a fireball that either did:
14 damage to one target (x=14, no extra targets), or
6 damage to two targets (x=13, 1 extra target), or
4 damage to three targets (x=12, 2 extra targets), or
2 damage to four targets (x=11, 3 extra targets), or
2 damage to five targets (x=10, 4 extra targets), or
1 damage to six targets (x=9, 5 extra targets), or
1 damage to seven targets (x=8, 6 extra targets).

In conclusion: Up to five grizzly bearGrizzly Bears died this day, or seven Infantry Veterans. Truly it was a sad day.

201208: Xira Arien.author: NeverendingDream
201208: Xira Arien.text_parsed:
I play Xira as an EDH general, she's great. She draws cards whenever you have extra mana, or when you absolutely need whatever you tutored for with Liliana Vess. Today I saved a Life from the Loam by using her to dredge it in response to a Relic of Progenitus activation... plus she has flying so can chump the bigger generals if you need another turn to find an answer. I'd definitely recommend her for EDH!

(also come on, who can resist a Jund-colored Insect Wizard Jushi Apprentice? :D)

201208: Xira Arien.author: Trygon_Predator
201208: Xira Arien.text_parsed:
Ah, Xira Arien, the Jund-colored insect wizard who loves to dress up. I play her as my commander and most people don't even know she exists, which lets you lie low until you can get your deck going. The fact that her card draw is targetable allows some politics (hey, wanna draw that card you tutored?), and gives you something to do with her when you've got spare mana.

Some simple combos: Seedborn Muse for a card every turn, and Swarmyard for a regenerating aerial blocker.

201209: Arena of the Ancients.author: BobbySinclair
201209: Arena of the Ancients.text_parsed:
Wow, the people complaining about this card have obviously never played EDH. For 3 mana, you can instantly douse any Voltron deck, or where commanders need to tap to use abilities, and at the very least, hamper any EDH deck's plans. Krenko, Mob Boss? Heartless Hidetsugu? Jaya Ballard, Task Mage? Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker? Niv-Mizzet, the Firemind? Marrow-Gnawer? Visara the Dreadful? Zirilan of the Claw? Need I share more generals that you can completely douse?

Take general damage winning out of the question. Put it in a lifegain deck, and your opponent has got to mill you. Then chuck in a Elixir of immortality and laugh in their face. Don't forget to chuck in a Darksteel Forge to keep your Arena around, mind you. Then they've got to exile it.

And what about your own general? It's an artifact, so it'll fit in any deck. Tap your opponent's generals, then play your own. If they're not affected by tapping, all the better! Geth, Lord of the Vault, Grimgrin, Corpse-Born, Memnarch, Oona, Queen of the Fae, Sliver Queen, Zedruu the Greathearted. All these generals either aren't affected by tapping, or can easily be untapped.

And what abut some combos? Quest for Renewal? Leyline of Singularity? Urabrask the Hidden? Amulet of Vigor? Honestly, if you're still calling this card bad, and don't think that keeping your opponent's legendaries tapped for THREE COLOURLESS is one of the most OP abilities EVER, then you don't know how to play Magic.

201210: Desert Twister.author: GrimjawxRULES
201210: Desert Twister.text_parsed:
@scumbling1: Ripping a card to pieces is a way of destroying it, so in reality, if you want to, you could also crush, burn, impale or otherwise completely ruin your opponents' cards instead of ripping it to shreds.
Still, by tearing a card in pieces you are still destroying it, so the game doesn't really distinguish between the two of them except for the way you have to destroy the card.

201210: Desert Twister.author: DrJack
201210: Desert Twister.text_parsed:
Yeah, yeah, Green's not supposed to be good at anything other than fat, ugly tramplers with ridiculously low casting costs and annoying 1/1 critters cluttering up the table.

But seriously, Desert Twister should cost 3GG, then it would be just right. Green has been able to clear artifacts, enchantments, and lands each for 2G or less, since the earliest days of Magic. Adding creatures to the kill list demands a somewhat more expensive cost, since one of Green's weaknesses... hah, I mean, one of the weaknesses Green is SUPPOSED to have, is getting rid of creatures easily.

3GG!! Sorcery!! Destroys any permanent in play!! Yeah boy!!!

201211: Gaea's Touch.author: LeakyBucket
201211: Gaea's Touch.text_parsed: With mono green this is so much better than Exploration for acceleration.  Exploration will give you maybe Four lands on turn two so four mana.  With Gaea's Touch you have five at worst and if you start with an Elvish Spirit Guide you have at least six mana by turn two (assuming 4 lands in the first 8 cards).  You can do even better with a lucky draw since Touch banks mana for you.

Mono-green:

T1: Forest, Llanowar Elves

T3: Forest (or sac the Touch) Primalcrux

201215: Palladia-Mors.author: kiseki
201215: Palladia-Mors.text_parsed:
Often, if you put out a fatty, and you attack with it every turn killing a chump blocker, you come out ahead. However, for the other four elder dragon legends, that is insufficient, since you have to pay three mana every turn for the privilege of killing the one-drop falcons. However, a flying fatty with trample is worth the mana to keep around.
For the EDLs, if your opponent has no flying defense, then they lose. For this one, they have to have robust flying defense or they loose.
201215: Palladia-Mors.text_posted:
Often, if you put out a fatty, and you attack with it every turn killing a chump blocker, you come out ahead.  However, for the other four elder dragon legends, that is insufficient, since you have to pay three mana every turn for the privilege of killing the one-drop falcons.  However, a flying fatty with trample is worth the mana to keep around.  
For the EDLs, if your opponent has no flying defense, then they lose.  For this one, they have to have robust flying defense or they loose.

201215: Palladia-Mors.author: DarthParallax
201215: Palladia-Mors.text_parsed:
compare to Nicol Bolas. lol they sure valued trample a LOT. WELL, compared to what creatures were capable of back then, honestly it made sense. Back then. If you're powering them out for lolz, then Palladia-Mors and Chromium tie in my book, but otherwise Weretarrasque is right.

If the re-did the Elder Dragons today, with the rule being 'same casting cost, same upkeep cost, all 7/7 flyers'

then I think we'd see more trample and first strike on the cycle, Chromium would have badass evasion, Bolas would be nerfed, and Arcaddes Sabboth would have something completely different and non-sucktastic. Vaevictus and Palladia would most closely resemble their original forms.

201215: Palladia-Mors.author: Radagast

Nicol Bolas was the odd-ball out, in that he was actually absurdly good for his casting cost, mainly because of silly interactions with other cards that would let you knock out a foe's hand early in the game. The rest of the Elder Dragons are mediocre, as one would expect.

201216: Firestorm Phoenix.author: Radagast
201216: Firestorm Phoenix.text_parsed:
Overcosted? Sure, especially by today's standards, but this was a very unusual card for its time. Creatures that were almost impossible to kill were hard to find back then, especially when they could come back from effects that would kill a regenerating creature. It's also a mid-sized red flyer, which was also somewhat unusual, so I can understand why WotC overbalanced it.

Definitely a card that should be revisited in a more cost-efficient form.

201216: Firestorm Phoenix.author: Aquillion
201216: Firestorm Phoenix.text_parsed:
It was a cool card (and at the time, its ability was pretty unique.) You can see how WotC was really cautious about this ability at first, too -- overcosted, with the weird rule that you can't play it again, etc. Amusing that only a little later they would print Enduring Renewal which broke the game wide open via a similar mechanic without that failsafe.

Sadly overcosted, but it was a neat idea. I could see it being useful in draft if used Legends for that, though I suppose any 3-attack flier is going to be useful in draft.

I can't believe it's not broken.

201220: Bazaar of Baghdad.author: jonb86
201220: Bazaar of Baghdad.text_parsed: Very VERY overrated card.  Vintage has been on the decline for 3 years now; everyone seems to be wanting to play Legacy these days over Vintage.  Even in Vintage the problem is, because everything is now based on the 1st or 2nd turn kills, you can no longer effectively take advantage of what this card does (it generally took at least 2 to 3 turns before anyone who played this card could fully take advantage of what it could do, and you rarely won the game the first turn you used this card).

201220: Bazaar of Baghdad.author: Werewolf-
201220: Bazaar of Baghdad.text_parsed:
This card shouldn't be anything less than five stars. Anyone who doesn't understand the power of this card doesn't have to look any further than dredge cards like Golgari Grave-Troll and Stinkweed Imp. This one land (which means it can't be countered) single-handedly enables a dredge deck to mill itself completely in only one or two turns, since you use the two draws to dredge and use the 3 discard to pitch your dredgers back in the grave. With one's entire library in his graveyard, all he has to do is Dread Return something that wins him the game immediately and gg.

Proxy a bazaar dredge deck and see for yourself. You can mulligan down to ONE CARD and still win the game in only two or three turns if that one card is Bazaar of Baghdad.

201220: Bazaar of Baghdad.author: DarthParallax
201220: Bazaar of Baghdad.text_parsed:
the only rational card to debate "is this better than Black Lotus?" Obviously it's Easy to just say "of course not, Lotus Is Best.", but the thing to remember is that this card is the reason why the Dredge Deck don't need to PLAY Black Lotus, and in fact even if it could probably wouldn't Most of the time, and when it deigns to, that's sort of uncommon for it.

A deck that has the right to be haughty enough to look at the Black Lotus sitting right in its binder and say "I don't think I'll use it today", even when acquistion of the Lotus is no barrier, is a deck that counts enough to be solely responsible for a card being able to contend with Black Lotus for the coveted 'Top Card in Game'.

Time Walk? Yawgmoth's Will? They want mana to play, and while YawgWin is super extraordinarily powerful even by Vintage standards, you can play your Yawgmoth's Will combos better and faster if you have Lotus and Ancestral Recall and Moxen and more draw (you get the point) to Hyperdrive your Ramp Into Win. The cards that you intend to pay mana to cast all point towards Black Lotus being the Best.

Bazaar of Baghdad and Dredge question that assumption. It's a fair debate to at least have, even if you think the results will say Lotus is Still Best.

201221: Ragnar.author: AnonymousNinja
201221: Ragnar.text_parsed:
Oh, there once was a hero named Ragnar the Red
Who came riding to Whiterun from old Rorikstead

And the braggart did swagger and brandish his blade
As he told of bold battles and gold he had made

But then he went quiet, did Ragnar the Red
When he met the shield-maiden Matilda, who said;

"Oh, you talk and you lie and you drink all our mead
Now I think it's high time that you lie down and bleed!"

And so then came clashing and slashing of steel
As the brave lass Matilda charged in, full of zeal

And the braggart named Ragnar was boastful no more-
When his ugly red head rolled around on the floor!

201223: Ramses Overdark.author: Enelysios
201223: Ramses Overdark.text_parsed:
Why does this thing have a rating as high as 3? That's above average.

First of all, that name... Oh man. Secondly, lots of neat combos here, but the problem is they are all terribly inefficient. In all the cases here Ramses is the most easily replaced and most expensive part of the combo. WIth something like False demise you would be better off just killing the creature conventionally or using a better card like The Avatar of Woe or even just a Royal Assassin, a conditional kill that is far more likely to appear and on a cheaper card.

Even wanting a legendary assassin for a theme EDH deck, thraximundar nets you another color, a beefier creature with haste and a neat ability for one more mana. This card just isn't good. Never was, and creatures have gotten better.

201224: Rasputin Dreamweaver.author: Mode
201224: Rasputin Dreamweaver.text_parsed:
This dude ain't too shabby at all.
It's something between Priest of Gix and Llanowar Elves (and Samite Healer), except that the mana he produces is colorless. And yeah, he can also prevent a considerable amount of damage. And he slowly restores his Dream Counters.
Too bad he does have this 7 counter restriction, otherwise Gilder Bairn would have been a nice choice.
But even just turning into and getting a 4/1 body sounds alright. Add Darkwater Catacombs or Azorius Signet and you can make sure to cast more spells if you still have one of these untapped.
Since he's a Human Wizard, you can put him in a Wizard deck. Putting him into play with Cryptic Gateway sounds efficient.
And since Humans are going to be a tribal type ( and ) in Innistrad, this might get more interesting for Legacy or Casual decks.

201224: Rasputin Dreamweaver.author: sonorhC
201224: Rasputin Dreamweaver.text_parsed:
@achilleselbow: There are a number of ways another creature might end up with dream counters on it. You could move some from Rasputin onto any creature with Leech Bonder, or you could have a card become a copy of Rasputin (presumably this would require either Mirror Gallery or copying from the graveyard). If that creature stopped being a copy of Rasputin, you could then increase the number of dream counters past seven, via Proliferate or Gilder Bairn. If it then became a copy of Rasputin again, that's when those rulings would kick in.

That aside, does anyone else think that one toughness is a bit odd? The real Rasputin was notoriously difficult to kill. Yeah, he can use his dream counters to prevent damage, but that doesn't really seem like enough to match the flavor.

201224: Rasputin Dreamweaver.author: NARFNra
201224: Rasputin Dreamweaver.text_parsed:
@longwinded

I finally found a way to get more than seven dream counters, but you can't put them on him. Play Bant.

Experiment Kraj + Fate Transfer

Come up with a way to get a +1/+1 counter on Rasputin, which shouldn't be hard with Kraj around, and then Fate Transfer the counters over. Now Kraj has

Remove a dream counter from Experiment Kraj: Add 1 to your mana pool.
Remove a dream counter from Experiment Kraj: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to Experiment Kraj this turn.

But no seven counters restriction! Yeah!

Stupidly costly and probably not worth it, but finally you can target him with Vorel of the Hull Clade and Gilder Bairn and other miscellaneous counter abilities.

201224: Rasputin Dreamweaver.author: IndubitableSalmon
201224: Rasputin Dreamweaver.text_parsed:
I'd really like to see this guy reprinted.
Up-to-date art, and a cleaned-up textbox would really do him a favour, and I see no reason to keep a card that's of no use in competitive Legacy/Vintage (yet of limitless potential in casual settings) so rare that even damaged versions are valued ~30$.

As for playability, he's probably one of the most interesting and fun creatures of his manacost - quite a direct threat with a power of 4, a good blocker and relatively hard to get rid of with his damage sponge, a mana factory, a beautiful ramp to beefy colorless effects and cards, say, a Sundering Titan, and your first address for flicker-effects.
Come to think of it, a deck with the Titan, Rasputin and some blinking (Momentary Blink, Deadeye Navigator, maybe the Vensers...) would be a pretty sweet one.

201226: Rohgahh of Kher Keep.author: Kserwin
201226: Rohgahh of Kher Keep.text_parsed:
Guys! Guys! This dude has a new use!

Commander card unveiled in his colors that creates Kobolds of Kher Keep equal to the amount of mana you spent on casting him whenever he enters the battlefield. Buff those bastards up to 2/3's with this guy in your Commander deck, plop in the Land that creates them too, and of course the original. Mini-combo you're not likely to play very often. But hidden and fun in the deck!

I love it when Magic makes references to old cards, or just directly take Creatures from old series and make them into Tokens or something.

Now I'd give this guy a 4/5 rating simply for that. Besides, the flavor of the card is pretty good as well. Generally well-designed card!

Edit: Dragon itself is Legendary, of course, costs 6 Mana (3 Colorless, 1 Black, 1 Red, 1 Green) has Flying, and can sacrifice a Creature to give himself +1/+0 until end of turn. Pretty nasty card even outside of Commander, I'd say.

Second edit: And of course, if it all goes wrong and somebody tries to mess up your strategy or you need the mana for something else. Just sacrifice this guy and ALL the Tokens to the Dragon. AMAZING synergy!

201226: Rohgahh of Kher Keep.author: Salient
201226: Rohgahh of Kher Keep.text_parsed:
The funniest way to enjoy this card is to get together a slew of Kobolds of Kher Keep in a multiplayer game, then just let them bounce around the table from player to player.

They drag themselves around from place to place, lollygag around tapped and unusable, feast and drink enough to become untapped, discover that you're not going to immediately pay them a crapton of mana, then sluff off to go mooch off someone else.

Rohgahh is the Scumbag Steve of Dominaria.

201230: Takklemaggot.author: longwinded
201230: Takklemaggot.text_parsed:
Listen, young ones, as I translate from the Old Tongue...

enchant creature. During the enchanted creature's controller's upkeep, put a -0/-1 counter on enchanted creature.

When enchanted creature dies, enchanted creature's controller choses another creature. If he does, attach Takklemaggot to that creature. If he cannot, Takklemaggot becomes a non-Aura enchantment, loses "enchant creature" and gains "At the beginning of the upkeep of the last player who controlled a creature enchanted by Takklemaggot, deal 1 damage to that player."

(This glossing over the "return to the battlefield under your control" dance that you must do when Takklemaggot is destroyed as a state-based action.)

Or, in plain speech: Takklemaggot infects a creature, and deals 1 "damage" (in the form of a -0/-1 counter) each upkeep. When that dies, it hops onto another creature (chosen by controller of last victim). If there are no creatures left, then Takklemaggot essentially infects that player, dealing one damage to him on each of his upkeeps.

Or, to be even plainer: it's black "hot potato".

If he cannot, Takklemaggot becomes a non-Aura enchantment, loses "enchant creature" and gains "At the beginning of the upkeep of the last player who controlled a creature enchanted by Takklemaggot, deal 1 damage to that player."[/i]

201230: Takklemaggot.author: kiseki
201230: Takklemaggot.text_parsed:
Two days ago, I saw a phyrexian dreadnought with Inviolability, and pariah on it. A Divine Presence was in play under the control of the same guy who controlled the Pariah. We had a guy with a desert twister in hand, but he couldn't cast it because a limited resources was in play. The game was completely stalled until someone placed this on one of my creatures.

Two turns later, it had shifted to the dreadnought, and TWELVE TURNS LATER the stalemate was broken and all the frustrated people at the table could say that they had seen a Takklemaggot kill a dreadnought!

201230: Takklemaggot.author: Jandrem
201230: Takklemaggot.text_parsed:
Hey guys, MANY of you are missing the ideal combo of this card. Put 4 of this bad boy in your deck, and make sure all your other creatures have PROTECTION FROM BLACK. Since all your creatures have PfB, you have NO LEGAL TARGETS. The instant the lil takklebuddy eats an opponent's creature, it either eats ANOTHER of his creatures, or just eats your opponent.

My takklemaggot deck has eaten many, many opponents. It's only weakness is how long it takes the maggots to do their thing, or any card that can destroy enchantments. Use tutors to get your maggots out quickly, cast some Cemetery Gates, and watch the fun.

The trick here is "legal targets", and warded creatures can't be targeted. You're welcome.

201233: Sword of the Ages.author: jonb86
201233: Sword of the Ages.text_parsed: This card was so good back in the day, it was actually banned in vintage for about 2 years during Magic's early days.  I still wonder why it was ever banned, since it was very difficult to untap artifacts on the same turn it came into play (tapped) and lots of fat creatures were hard to come by (the only thing I can think of is Ball Lightning+Berserk, no one blocks, and exile it for the win).  I have never ever heard of anyone building a deck around this card.  Though I did see someone play it in an EDH deck once; he actually won a game with it I heard by making a ton of 1/1s and exiling them to the sword for lethal damage (I think he used the old Squirrel Nest/Earthcraft combo to make the tokens)

201233: Sword of the Ages.author: drpvfx
201233: Sword of the Ages.text_parsed:
This is a really fun card in my "Gimmee" deck.

Granted, it's not as good as Diamond Valley in that regard,
but unlike DV, it can actually defeat your opponent.

It's fun in casual (esp. group games), but not at all tourney-worthy.

Also- why on earth do you think this card was banned at any point?
I've been playing since Legends was in print, and this is news to me.

AFAIK, The only card ever banned from t1 for being broken was Time Vault,
and even that one is legal now, despite being re-errata'd into godlike power.

The other bans are due to antes, card drop effects (Chaos Orb, Falling Star) or excessive timewasting (Shahrazad).

201234: Tetsuo Umezawa.author: allmighty_abacus
201234: Tetsuo Umezawa.text_parsed:
@achilleselbow

come on now, we aren't in the magic of yesteryear any more. This card IS lacking. First of all, it's a legend. You can only have one of these guys on the field at a time, which severely limits the usefulness of its ability. Secondly, it's casting cost is mediocre at best. Sure, better than most early creatures, but not remotely notable today. Being immune to enchantments is more of a hindrance than a benefit nowadays, as most people would sooner run path to exile than a pacifism. Finally, it's ability is NOT better than royal assassin. In fact it is worse if anything. You should go sit in a corner and think about how stupid that sounds. You have to pay 4 mana to use it, and you can only use it once a turn since it's a LEGEND. I'd just stick with 2 diabolic edicts. Which, by the way, has the same CMC. The ability to target blocking creatures isn't really that great, since you could always just use one of the legions of black creature-kill instants.

How did he almost kill Bolas anyway? Was he drugged and tethered down with his mouth sealed shut?

201234: Tetsuo Umezawa.author: jsttu
201234: Tetsuo Umezawa.text_parsed: @TPmanW: actually, his abilities make sense flavorwise. He was the Imperial champion of the Madaran Empire, so if anyone put up a fight, represented by blocking or tapped, he would come in and respectfully kick their asses until they gave in or died. His second ability references his feud with Ramses Overdark, who has the ability to kill a creature who is enchanted. since he is unable to be enchanted, he wins, just like he did in the story. I am not quite sure how Bolas fits into the card though, maybe he managed to tap him when the body was destroyed by the hammer? Anyway, I hope that clears the flavor issues up a little.

201235: Gauntlets of Chaos.author: Mode
201235: Gauntlets of Chaos.text_parsed:
"Hey its definitely a playable card! Steal (their) bomb and give them a Bronze Bombshell or something!
Can be game changing, with only 5 mana invested over two turns." -achilleselbow

Well, the problem here is the "only 5 mana invested over two turns" part.
Your opponent has a turn to get rid of the gauntlets, or another turn to get rid of whatever you got from him, and still have a good amount of mana left for other stuff. Or he'll just get rid of you entirely while you're busy preparing the shenanigans in turn 5 and 6, which isn't too unlikely in agressive decks since, aussuming you want to keep your bombshell, you'll just have some defense from your first three turns.

201235: Gauntlets of Chaos.author: YoungSloshee
201235: Gauntlets of Chaos.text_parsed:
I will forever respect and hate this card.

I ran a changeling deck and cast a Reaper King while my opponents weren't running good creature removal decks (one with a white deck with two Swords to Ploughshares in the graveyard, and the other with an old-school artifact deck that messes with colorless mana). I was pretty confident in my position until Mr. Artifact pulled out the Gauntlets and traded my King for a 1/1 changeling token I made earlier with Crib Death.

Oh, then he swung a Colossus of Sardia into my face.
